The Amazon deal is so big for Affirm... Actually $AMZN will benefit tremendously too. Their ecommerce margins are so slim, now with the opportunity of earning a slice of the payment fees, even a tiny sliver, will unlock a new revenue stream for Amazon. Affirm is a direct payment gateway interacting with the consumer and the merchant all under one roof, which makes their business model so attractive. Think about how many layers take place in credit card transactions today. Consumer's checking account pays the credit card issuer, and on the merchant side there are so many intermediaries that pass through funds between $V and $MA and till they arrive to the merchant. $AFRM, even though they utilize existing banks and credit cards as form of payments, is a truly end-to-end experience, and as they grow they can educate consumers to lean towards using their own branded cards, such as the Affirm Debit+ expected to be released next week.

Mastercard Rolls Out 'Buy Now, Pay Later' Installment Option in US, UK, Australia11:03 AM ET, 09/28/2021 - MT Newswires11:03 AM EDT, 09/28/2021 (MT Newswires) -- Mastercard said Tuesday it has rolled out a "buy now, pay later" program for customers the US, Australia, and the UK in a push to meet growing consumer demand for more payment options.The new BNPL program, called Mastercard Installments, allows customers to pay for their online and in-store purchases through equally sized, interest-free installments using the Mastercard global network."People want more from their money with greater flexibility and control in how they pay and where they shop," Craig Vosburg, Mastercard's chief product officer, said in a statement. "Mastercard Installments has been built on our guiding principles to protect consumers and enable choice without sacrificing trust and security."

While there isn't any major news today, it's worth noting that there has been some concerning data to emerge about the BNPL space as a whole. One study released last week found that one-third of U.S. consumers who used a BNPL service had fallen behind on at least one payment. A separate study found that about 10% of BNPL consumers in the U.K. were facing collection activity.To be clear, BNPL continues to be a red-hot growth industry for now and there's nothing in Affirm's latest earnings results to indicate that any consumer activity is a problem for the business. But these trends are certainly worth monitoring as the industry grows.

FWIW, here is part of a note from Jim Cramer's advisory letter on MA. His charitable trust added to its position yesterday.Lastly, regarding any pressure resulting from Buy Now, Pay Later (BNPL) products, as Jim and Jeff previously discussed during the Daily Rundown, here, with international travel expected to rebound and consumers set to return to experiential activities, such as dining out, we think buyers will continue to reach for traditional credit cards thanks to the rewards points programs this payment method offers, unlike BNPL products such as Affirm (AFRM) .As a result, given our belief that the supply dynamic is transient, that the demand will sustain and ultimately be met thanks to the strength of consumer balance sheets, and that Mastercard serves as a natural hedge against the still uncertain inflation dynamic, we view the weakness as an opportunity to add exposure and reduce our overall cost basis as shares are trading roughly $12 below or last buy level.

Note from Credit Suisse on AFRM...........BNPL Remains a Nascent Payment Method: As of 2020, BNPL claimed just ~1.6%penetration (Worldpay estimate) of the US eCommerce market vs. ~6% in EMEA as of 2019,with much higher penetration in select markets (e.g., 25% in Sweden, ~18% in Germany,~8% in Australia). As a highly attractive offering for tech-savvy millennial and Gen Zconsumers who are more distrustful of traditional financial institutions and products, Affirmenables these consumers to obtain financing for purchases without risk of hidden fees, latefees, or surprise interest charges. Worldpay forecasts BNPL to grow to ~3% penetration ofUS eCommerce volumes by 2023, representing ~$50b, and we estimate that AFRM couldclaim ~35% market share.BNPL is clearly going to take more and more share away from CC's.

Mastercard has been a weak performer lately, but shares are finally waking up today and we see a couple of reasons for the solid 3% move. First up is the surprise retail sales beat for September. A retail sales beat is always a great sign of a healthy consumer who is willing to spend. And when the consumer spends, they are more likely to do so with plastic and electronic payments over paper, representing the secular shift that has and will continue to play into Mastercard’s favor for years to come. Second, cross-border travel is about to get a big boost. The White House announced this morning that fully vaccinated international travelers from the European Union, United Kingdom, and other countries are allowed into the United States beginning November 8th. This is fanatic news for Mastercard. Cross-border volumes — a high margin business —is what has lagged throughout the economic recovery because of countries closing their borders in an effort to slow the spread of COVID-19. But with the U.S. opening its doors to visitors, cross-border spending is soon about to get the much-needed jolt that Mastercard needs for better earnings.

First, if someone has high net-worth and wishes to invest-and-forget and sleep soundly knowing assets are well-positioned for the very long term, perhaps high returns are more safely and reliably expected with, for example AAPL and/or MSFT.However, I've analyzed MA by doing the following:1. Bring up the MA chart, full screen2. Have the time span be 2 years3. Go to the indicators and bring up the "Williams %R" using the default settings, i.e., a 14-day period, -20 indicating overbought and -80 indicating oversold.3a. Note: I use the Williams %R value to inform me of an entry point to buy stock, provided the company is financially healthy, has a competitive business model, has a well-recognized and well-respected brand.4. Notice MA's Williams %R was about -98, i.e., extremely oversold, on 03SEPT. Please also note MA's William %R has been this oversold on very few occasions in the past 2 years...and each time it has recovered fairly well.5. Finally, please see MA's price peaks on, or about, 4/29/2021 & 7/29/2021, followed by the price declines in-between. I believe this may be due to stock traders taking profits when MA reports healthy earnings, then buying back-in between MA's earning periods. The next MA earning report is on, or about 10/28 or 29/2021.My hypothesis is that MA will increase [overall] from here as the next earnings date approaches.I respectfully ask for your thoughts.
